comments.value: Do you recall our database of postcodes / regions which we purchased from the Office of National Statistics to allow us to look up regions on the basis of postcodes? I have someone internally here who would like to use it - do you still have the disk or could you forward me the contents so I can share it with them? Also, do you think we need to purchase an updated version - I know the current one is a couple of years old.

Hi Morag,

The last version we have is Nov 2008 I have put it on the live servers under a password for you.

http://webservices.london2012.com/nspdc_nov_2008_uk_100m_pp.csv.zip 
http://webservices.london2012.com/postcode-lookups.zip 
http://webservices.london2012.com/postcode-namesandcodes.zip 
passwd: locog/l0c0g

I have also attached the user doc to this ticket.

This is the data set you have [UK Core 100m PP DVD]
http://www.statistics.gov.uk/geography/nspd.asp 

Are updates low cost? if so then might be worth getting a new copy to Stamen. But I think for what we use it for your probably OK there is talk of the right to the postcode data being changed shortly as part of the data.gov project so may be worth waiting to see if that happens.Am I right in thinking the ONS data wasn't that expensive (do you mind sharing if you know as I would be interested?)

Nearer to the games I imagine you will almost certainly require an update as all the approach roads to the new site won't be in the old data set. Althogu you (or the ODA) probably have a better idea when that is going to happen!

Jamie

Perfect - thanks so much!

You're right, the ONS data wasn't expensive - I seem to remember it was only Â£4-5k, though rates vary depending on the type of organisation doing the purchasing (public vs. private).

As you say, we're probably all right to use the data we have for the time being - though an update will be essential when the venues get postcodes too!

cool, this looks good. What do you think makes the most sense in terms of functionality?  Do you think it'd be strange to click on the 'bigger' image of the video in the switcher and then have this open, and then click on the play button for it to work?  Too many steps?

Thanks Liz,

I think we need the bigger video thumb (or video) to appear first, we can't go straight from the small thumb straight to a pop up.

The simplest would be to make video work like the Webcams, where when you click on the main/larger thumbnail you go to the actual video/webcam page.

Although the video is way to small to watch at the current size, I like the idea of selecting a video, see it play a bit and then deciding it's too small and expanding it, closing it and then maybe selecting another video to play in situ. (or in a bigger pop up).

We could make the small video appear but have an overlay or icon (that always appears or just you roll over the video) that says 'click here to view video full size'.

In terms of Javascript, the video won't even load without Javascript turned on. I *think* we currently show a message saying you need Flash and Javascript to view this video.

Before we go any further I think we need to decide:

- Do we show a real video at the small size or do we just display a click-able image (I prefer the small video I think as it shows you it's video)
- Do we then show the larger video in a pop-up or just take the user though to the relevant video page (a pop up allows the user to watch multiple videos without leaving the home page)

comments.value:
Previously, translated pages were placed into the appropriate section after they came back from translation based on the translated section name. This meant that inadvertent differences in section translation led to pages gong astray. Now, the section is known in advance and there is no possibility of the page going into the wrong section.

The other driving factor behind this refactoring is that it removes a level of abstraction. Until now we (effectively) had a "translations" table which showed which page had been translated when. However, now this information all lives in the french page's workflow (see attached).
This work will take an estimated 5 days to complete.
Morag asks: "is it safe to actually say the refactoring is somewhat done, but not front-end?"

This ticket is part of the French site launch: http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/438, which is due on February 28. Therefore I have changed the due date for this to Feb 28 (although I believe the this work is already done). Not billable because being billed as part of the site launch.
This ticket was closed and merged into ticket #438 "French site handover".

subject: Refactoring of translation
description:
Previously, translated pages were placed into the appropriate section after they came back from translation based on the translated section name. This meant that inadvertent differences in section translation led to pages gong astray. Now, the section is known in advance and there is no possibility of the page going into the wrong section.

The other driving factor behind this refactoring is that it removes a level of abstraction. Until now we (effectively) had a "translations" table which showed which page had been translated when. However, now this information all lives in the french page's workflow (see attached).

Had a look through these (once Liz explained where to find them) but
believe there are still some gaps:

 

I am unclear about why we have two sections - Tutorials and 2012
Tutorials - can we just have one?

 

I think there is some key content missing on functionality e.g.
Publications, Future opportunities, ODA suppliers, page locking and
embargoeing, News and Media releases, Blog, Assigning stories, Home page
modules, Scrolling feature modules etc.

abilities - including people who don't have much of a clue about how the
CMS works.

 

Can you review the screens in the light of these comments? Happy to
discuss.

 

Thanks!
